message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border is common with ventricular septal defect and is graded IV based on the intensity of the murmur. The fact that the pediatrician reassures the parents that the infant will be monitored but most likely will not require surgical intervention also supports the diagnosis of ventricular septal defect, which often closes on its own. Atrial septal defect may also present with a murmur, but it is usually mid-systolic and not as intense. Tetralogy of Fallot and patent ductus arteriosus would likely present with different clinical features and murmurs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD). VSD is a congenital heart defect that involves an abnormal opening in the ventricular septum. Surgical intervention is not always necessary for VSD, as it can sometimes close on its own or may not cause significant symptoms. Atrial septal defect and patent ductus arteriosus also involve abnormal openings in the heart, but the location and characteristics of the murmur suggest VSD. Tetralogy of Fallot involves a combination of several heart defects and typically presents with different symptoms than those described for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A loud holosystolic murmur heard at the left sternal border suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Depending on the size and location of the VSD, surgical intervention may or may not be necessary. Atrial septal defect could also cause a murmur but does not typically have a loud holosystolic component. Tetralogy of Fallot and patent ductus arteriosus may both cause a murmur, but they do not usually present with a loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination findings of a loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border and the age of the patient suggest a ventricular septal defect. The echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis and the indication that surgical intervention may not be required suggests a smaller defect that may resolve on its own.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD). This is further supported by the echocardiogram findings and the fact that the pediatrician reassured the parents that surgical intervention is most likely not needed. Atrial septal defect (ASD) and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) may also present with a murmur but do not typically have as loud of a murmur as VSD. Tetralogy of Fallot usually presents with a cyanotic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD). VSD is often asymptomatic in early infancy and early surgery is not usually necessary unless there are severe symptoms or complications. Atrial septal defect (ASD) can present with a systolic murmur, but it is typically not as loud or at the left sternal border. Tetralogy of Fallot and patent ductus arteriosus are less likely based on the presentation and symptoms provided.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border indicates a ventricular septal defect. Surgical intervention is often not required for small defects, and the infant will be monitored for any changes or symptoms. Atrial septal defect and patent ductus arteriosus usually don't cause a loud holosystolic murmur, and Tetralogy of Fallot is associated with cyanosis and other symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border (grade IV) suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD). VSDs are a common congenital heart defect and can vary in severity. Based on echocardiogram findings, the physician reassured the parents that surgical intervention is most likely unnecessary. This is because small VSDs may close on their own without treatment while larger ones may require surgery. Atrial septal defects and patent ductus arteriosus can also cause murmur but are less likely with the given symptoms, and Tetralogy of Fallot has a different set of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, particularly the loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, suggest a ventricular septal defect. Atrial septal defects and patent ductus arteriosus usually have a systolic ejection murmur. Tetralogy of Fallot presents with a harsh systolic ejection murmur with a prominent S2.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border (grade IV) is indicative of ventricular septal defect (VSD). The fact that the echocardiogram confirms the diagnosis but surgical intervention is not needed suggests that the VSD is small and not causing major hemodynamic effects. Atrial septal defect (ASD), Tetralogy of Fallot, and Patent ductus arteriosus can also cause heart murmurs, but their characteristic murmurs are different from VSD.
